text: the truck bomb had been made with
home-brewed explosives packed inside
industrial pipes and an old water tank
then concealed was freshly clipped
branches the tasks tonight for these
anti-government fighters is to destroy
an army checkpoint at the entrance to
Syria's largest city
this is CJ chippers for The New York
Times in Syria's Aleppo Governorate what
began for these men with nonviolent
protests early last year has become an
escalating guerrilla campaign once on
the defensive these rebels now confident
and organized say they will accept
nothing short of the end with President
Bashar al-assad
this 52 main unit calls itself the Lions
of al tau P it is one of hundreds of
local units loosely assembled under the
banner of the Free Syrian Army the
majority of the men are army defectors
though the group's founders are
civilians one man sold real estate
another was a nurse who owned a
short-order restaurant during five days
in August
these men allowed the New York Times to
document their war their commander Abdul
Hakim Yasin is a formerly clean-shaven
accountant and the father of two young
boys outside support is scarce Hakim and
his fighters rely on smuggled or
captured firearms and makeshift weapons
from local workshops much of the war is
shifted from the countryside to Aleppo
this day was no different after being
issued weapons and ammunition some men
fell silent the drive to Aleppo must be
fast to avoid attacks from government
aircraft the roads are nearly deserted
Aleppo is a city of a few million people
most remained inside by day seeking
shelter from shelling and air strikes
how came in his men move into an
apartment abandoned by a police captain
who was loyal to the regime the
captain's personal possessions had
fallen into the rebels hands
government jets and helicopters patrol
overhead will beam by darkness can
reduce risk though does not a guarantee
even then ordnance can strike clothes
and bullets fly
on this night Hakim was preparing to
destroy a checkpoint with the truck bomb
which could open a new route into the
city then came a surprise
Hakeem's father who had been jailed for
weeks maletto called to say he'd been
released he needed a ride how came it
long worried that his father's arrest
was a trap designed to lure him from the
shadows he'd expected his father to be
killed or used as bait after driving
almost a half hour they reached a
rendezvous point near Aleppo
[Music]
back and tell her fot the fighters
dropped off Akeem his father and
celebrated his release
euphoria soon gave way to work the
weapons were ready to plan almost
complete
the base had another recent arrival Abu
allow a prisoner the rebel said he was
an ex-convict would confess to killing
six people and raping a woman while
fighting in the shabiha one of the
militias loyal to the government bruises
covered him whoever had held him before
this night
had beaten him severely the rebels tell
of will allow that he will soon be freed
allowed to drive a car to meet his
father at a checkpoint part of a
prisoner exchange don't either he nor
the two journalists present knew it he
was being duped Abu Allah would be
driving the truck bomb which had been
rigged for remote detonation he was not
to be freed he was to be an unwitting
suicide bomber shortly before dawn the
rebels blindfolded Abu halau and sat him
in a pickup truck that would accompany
the bomb near the checkpoint he'd be
unmasked told he was free and put behind
the trucks steering wheel hours later
the fighters returned dejected
prisoner had fallen for their deception
and driven to the target the bomb did
not explode at the house of former
government official the men cooled off
in the war war moves too capricious
rhythms under the rules that shape
serious violence both Hakeem's father
and Hakeem's prisoner had been presumed
dead
both men survived for a dawn Hakim did
not think they would see it is he said
the game of fate
